On 04/03/2008, name zero <namezero911@...> wrote:
>  What I am looking for is a way to "record" (like recording macros in M$ Office) all interactions with a specific class (including all its methods), which means that it records the invoked method calls itself, the parameters, as well as the returned result(object)s. The workflow would be easy: I make sure that the database layer and the layer I want to test works (it has to call the correct database-layer methods) and then I run the test in "record-mode". After that I can start the tests in replay mode, I don't need to use the database object itself anymore but instead the cached results are returned, however, still with the mock-object characteristics (if the methods of the mockobject aren't called in the correct order or with wrong parameters I would get an exception).


This will result in very brittle tests because it will overly
constrain the number and order of calls and exact parameter values,
many of which will be irrelevant to the test.  Any change to your
objects will then break your tests for no real reason.

If you're worried about performance, you could use an in-memory
database (E.g. HSQLDB, http://hsqldb.org/) for testing instead of mock
objects.

Mock objects are tool for test *driven* development.  They help you
design the communication protocols between your objects.  JMock has
many features that let you describe a protocol to be followed in a
test, not the exact sequence of calls that will occur.  E.g. you can
allow or ignore some calls, expect a minimum number of calls, loosen
constraints on parameter values or ignore parameters altogether,
expect calls to occur only when the object is in a specific state, and
so on.

In my experience, the result of using mock objects in TDD is an OO
design in which objects are loosely coupled, talk in a "Tell, Don't
Ask" style and the inter-object protocols are an important aspect of
the design.  In a system that has been written without tests and mock
objects (again, in my experience), classes are more tightly coupled,
there are many static functions and objects have many getters and
setters.  This style of code does not lend itself well to testing with
mock objects.

--Nat
